1043.original:
H-0089.1
HOUSE BILL 1043
State of Washington
69th Legislature
2025 Regular Session
ByRepresentatives Wylie, Doglio, Fey, Ramel, Shavers, Fosse, Salahuddin, Reeves, and Hill
Prefiled 12/11/24.Read first time 01/13/25.Referred to Committee on Finance.
AN ACT Relating to commute trip reduction tax credit; amending RCW 82.70.020, 82.70.040, and 82.70.900; creating a new section; providing an effective date; and declaring an emergency.
BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON:
Sec. 1. RCW 82.70.020 and 2024 c 310 s 608 are each amended to read as follows:
(1) Employers in this state who are taxable under chapter 82.04 or 82.16 RCW and provide financial incentives to their own or other employees for ride sharing, for using public transportation, for using car sharing, or for using nonmotorized commuting before January 1, ((2025))2035, are allowed a credit against taxes payable under chapters 82.04 and 82.16 RCW for amounts paid to or on behalf of employees for ride sharing in vehicles carrying two or more persons, for using public transportation, for using car sharing, or for using nonmotorized commuting, not to exceed (($60))$100 per employee per fiscal year.
(2) Property managers who are taxable under chapter 82.04 or 82.16 RCW and provide financial incentives to persons employed at a worksite in this state managed by the property manager for ride sharing, for using public transportation, for using car sharing, or for using nonmotorized commuting before January 1, ((2024))2035, are allowed a credit against taxes payable under chapters 82.04 and 82.16 RCW for amounts paid to or on behalf of these persons for ride sharing in vehicles carrying two or more persons, for using public transportation, for using car sharing, or for using nonmotorized commuting, not to exceed (($60))$100 per person per fiscal year.
(3) The credit under this section is equal to the amount paid to or on behalf of each employee multiplied by 50 percent, but may not exceed (($60))$100 per employee per fiscal year. No refunds may be granted for credits under this section.
(4) A person may not receive credit under this section for amounts paid to or on behalf of the same employee under both chapters 82.04 and 82.16 RCW.
(5) A person may not take a credit under this section for amounts claimed for credit by other persons.
Sec. 2. RCW 82.70.040 and 2024 c 310 s 609 are each amended to read as follows:
(1)(a) The department must keep a running total of all credits allowed under RCW 82.70.020 during each fiscal year. The department may not allow any credits that would cause the total amount allowed to exceed (($2,750,000))$4,300,000 in any fiscal year.
(b) If the total amount of credit applied for by all applicants in any year exceeds the limit in this subsection, the department must ratably reduce the amount of credit allowed for all applicants so that the limit in this subsection is not exceeded. If a credit is reduced under this subsection, the amount of the reduction may not be carried forward and claimed in subsequent fiscal years.
(2)(a) Tax credits under RCW 82.70.020 may not be claimed in excess of the amount of tax otherwise due under chapter 82.04 or 82.16 RCW.
(b) Through June 30, 2005, a person with taxes equal to or in excess of the credit under RCW 82.70.020, and therefore not subject to the limitation in (a) of this subsection, may elect to defer tax credits for a period of not more than three years after the year in which the credits accrue. For credits approved by the department through June 30, 2015, the approved credit may be carried forward and used for tax reporting periods through December 31, 2016. Credits approved after June 30, 2015, must be used for tax reporting periods within the calendar year for which they are approved by the department and may not be carried forward to subsequent tax reporting periods. Credits carried forward as authorized by this subsection are subject to the limitation in subsection (1)(a) of this section for the fiscal year for which the credits were originally approved.
(3) No person may be approved for tax credits under RCW 82.70.020 in excess of (($100,000))$50,000 in any fiscal year. This limitation does not apply to credits carried forward from prior years under subsection (2)(b) of this section.
(4) No person may claim tax credits after June 30, ((2025))2035.
Sec. 3. RCW 82.70.900 and 2024 c 310 s 610 are each amended to read as follows:
This chapter expires July 1, ((2025))2035.
NEW SECTION.  Sec. 4. RCW 82.32.808 does not apply to this act.
NEW SECTION.  Sec. 5. This act is necessary for the immediate preservation of the public peace, health, or safety, or support of the state government and its existing public institutions, and takes effect July 1, 2025.
--- END ---
1043.summary:
Purpose

The purpose of House Bill 1043 is to amend existing laws regarding tax credits for commute trip reduction in Washington State. The bill aims to extend the deadlines for these tax credits from 2025 to 2035, increasing the maximum possible tax credit from $60 to $100 per employee per fiscal year. This change is designed to encourage employers and property managers to provide financial incentives for their employees to use more sustainable forms of commuting, such as ride sharing, public transportation, car sharing, and nonmotorized commuting. The amendment seeks to broaden the impact of the tax credits and support environmental initiatives.

Key Provisions

Tax Credit Amounts

  • Employers providing financial incentives for sustainable commuting methods can earn a tax credit up to $100 per employee per fiscal year.
  • Property managers offering similar incentives to employees can also receive a tax credit up to $100 per individual per fiscal year.
  • The credit equals 50% of the amount paid to or on behalf of each employee, capped at $100.

Credit Limitations

  • The total amount of tax credits awarded by the state may not exceed $4,300,000 in any fiscal year. If applications exceed this limit, credits will be reduced proportionately.
  • Tax credits cannot be claimed if they exceed the total tax owed under applicable tax laws.
  • Individuals cannot receive credits for the same expense claimed by someone else, and no refunds are granted for credits.

Expiration and Extension

  • The bill extends the expiration date of the tax credits from July 1, 2025, to July 1, 2035, allowing continued support for commute trip reduction efforts.

Additional Sections

  • A new section states that certain prior regulations (RCW 82.32.808) do not apply to this act, indicating a specificity to this bill.
  • The act is determined crucial for public health, safety, and governmental support, with an effective date of July 1, 2025.

1043-S.summary:
Purpose

The edits made to Substitute House Bill 1043 primarily aim to extend the deadlines and increase certain financial caps related to the commute trip reduction tax credit program in Washington State. The overall goal is to provide additional time and enhanced benefits to employers and property managers who incentivize eco-friendly commuting options, thereby promoting more sustainable transportation practices among employees. The changes extend eligibility periods and increase tax credit limits, making it more appealing for businesses to support alternative commuting methods.

Key Changes

Deadlines Extended

  • The deadline for providing financial incentives has been changed from January 1, 2025, to January 1, 2035, for both employers and property managers.
  • The expiration date of the tax credit program has also been moved from July 1, 2025, to July 1, 2035.

Financial Credit Increases

  • The maximum tax credit available per employee or person has been increased from $60 to $100 per fiscal year.
  • The tax credit under section 1 is no longer multiplied by 50 percent, meaning the entire amount paid for qualified commuting options can directly be claimed (subject to the annual cap of $100).

Credit Limits Adjusted

  • The overall cap on the total amount of tax credits allowed in a fiscal year has increased from $2,750,000 to $4,300,000.
  • The individual credit limit per person in a fiscal year has been reduced from $100,000 to $50,000 (the specifics for previous credits have been clarified).

These updates are intended to enhance the state's initiatives to encourage and support eco-conscious commuting solutions, potentially leading to reduced traffic congestion and lower carbon emissions.
